# List of large aircraft

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Giant_planes_comparison_-
_Updated.svg/300px-Giant_planes_comparison_-
_Updated.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Giant_planes_comparison_-_Updated.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Giant_planes_comparison_-_Updated.svg "Enlarge")

A size comparison of four of the largest aircraft.

This is a **list of large aircraft**.

The US [Federal Aviation Administration](/wiki/Federal_Aviation_Administration
"Federal Aviation Administration") defines a [large
aircraft](/wiki/Large_aircraft "Large aircraft") as any aircraft with a
certificated [maximum takeoff weight](/wiki/Maximum_takeoff_weight "Maximum
takeoff weight") of more than 12,500 lb (5,700 kg) [1]

The [European Aviation Safety Agency](/wiki/European_Aviation_Safety_Agency
"European Aviation Safety Agency") (EASA) defines a large aircraft as either
"an aeroplane with a maximum take-off mass of more than 5,700 kilograms
(12,600 pounds) or a multi-engined helicopter."[2]

## Fixed-
wing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_large_aircraft&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Fixed-wing")]

###
Civilian[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_large_aircraft&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Civilian")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Stratolaunch_comparison.svg/220px-
Stratolaunch_comparison.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Stratolaunch_comparison.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Stratolaunch_comparison.svg "Enlarge")

Wingspan comparison of the Stratolaunch carrier with other large airplanes

In Service Aircraft | First flight | Note  
---|---|---  
[Antonov An-225 Mriya](/wiki/Antonov_An-225_Mriya "Antonov An-225 Mriya") | 19881221 !21 December 1988 | Generally acknowledged as the largest airplane in the world, the single Antonov An-225 is the world's heaviest aircraft ever ([maximum takeoff weight](/wiki/Maximum_takeoff_weight "Maximum takeoff weight") greater than 640 [tons](/wiki/Ton "Ton")) and the largest [heavier-than-air aircraft](/wiki/Aircraft#Heavier-than-air_.E2.80.93_aerodynes "Aircraft") (in length and wingspan) ever entering operational service.  
[Airbus A380-800](/wiki/Airbus_A380-800 "Airbus A380-800") [3] | 20050427 !27 April 2005 | The largest passenger aircraft ever made. Capable of carrying 850 passengers  
[Airbus A340-600](/wiki/Airbus_A340#A340-600 "Airbus A340") | 20010423 !23 April 2001 | The A340-600 has been in production since 2001, with a length of 75.30 m, the longest commercial aircraft, until surpassed by the [Boeing 747-8](/wiki/Boeing_747-8 "Boeing 747-8").  
[Antonov An-124](/wiki/Antonov_An-124 "Antonov An-124") | 19820000 !26 December 1982 | Was the largest mass-produced aircraft in the world until the [Airbus A380](/wiki/Airbus_A380 "Airbus A380") was produced. Remains the world's largest military aircraft currently in service.  
[Antonov An-22](/wiki/Antonov_An-22 "Antonov An-22") | 19650227 !27 February 1965 | World's largest turboprop-powered airplane  
[Boeing 747-8](/wiki/Boeing_747-8 "Boeing 747-8") | 20100208 !8 February 2010 (F variant) | Lengthened version of 747 with increased wingspan. World's longest passenger aircraft at 76.4 m (0.9 m / 3 ft longer than Airbus A340)[4] capacity of 650 passengers.  
[Boeing 747](/wiki/Boeing_747 "Boeing 747")[5] | 19690209 !9 February 1969 | Highest-capacity passenger aircraft until surpassed by Airbus A380  
[Boeing 747 "Dreamlifter"](/wiki/Boeing_747_Large_Cargo_Freighter "Boeing 747 Large Cargo Freighter") | 20060909 !9 September 2006 | 747 with enlarged fuselage for transporting [Boeing 787 Dreamliner](/wiki/Boeing_787_Dreamliner "Boeing 787 Dreamliner") sub-assemblies (1,800 cubic metres (65,000 cu ft))  
[Tupolev _Maksim Gorki_](/wiki/Tupolev_ANT-20 "Tupolev ANT-20") | 19340519 !19 May 1934 | Physically the largest aircraft, and heaviest land-based aircraft of the 1930s era (63 meter/206.7 ft wingspan, 53 tonne MTOW), required eight 900 hp Mikulin V12 engines for flight  
[Dornier Do X](/wiki/Dornier_Do_X "Dornier Do X") | 19290712 !12 July 1929 | Largest successful flying boat and heaviest aircraft in the world from 1929 until 1942 when the [Boeing B-29 Superfortress](/wiki/Boeing_B-29_Superfortress "Boeing B-29 Superfortress") first flew.  
[Antonov An-2](/wiki/Antonov_An-2 "Antonov An-2") | 19470831 !31 August 1947 | Largest mass-produced single-engine biplane.  
  
###
Military[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_large_aircraft&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Military")]

Aircraft | First flight | Note  
---|---|---  
[Blohm & Voss BV 238](/wiki/Blohm_%26_Voss_BV_238 "Blohm & Voss BV 238") | 19440311 !11 March 1944 | Very large flying boat. The largest aircraft in the world 1944 to 1945 when the single one was destroyed. The even heavier [Convair B-36](/wiki/Convair_B-36 "Convair B-36") first flew in 1946. Heaviest aircraft built during [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), and largest aircraft produced by any of the Axis powers in World War II  
[Douglas XB-19](/wiki/Douglas_XB-19 "Douglas XB-19")[6] | 19410627 !27 June 1941 | This experimental aircraft was the largest US bomber until 1946 when the [Northrop YB-35](/wiki/Northrop_YB-35 "Northrop YB-35") flew.  
[Boeing B-29 Superfortress](/wiki/Boeing_B-29_Superfortress "Boeing B-29 Superfortress")[7] | 19420921 !21 September 1942 | Largest aircraft in the world from 1942 to 1943 when the even heavier [Junkers Ju-390](/wiki/Junkers_Ju-390 "Junkers Ju-390") first flew. It was one of the largest bombers used during [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II")  
[Convair B-36 Peacemaker](/wiki/Convair_B-36_Peacemaker "Convair B-36 Peacemaker")[8] | 19460808 !8 August 1946 | Largest aircraft in the world 1946 to 1947 when the even heavier [Hughes H-4 Hercules](/wiki/Hughes_H-4_Hercules "Hughes H-4 Hercules") first flew. First intercontinental strategic bomber, longest wingspan for a combat aircraft  
[Convair XC-99](/wiki/Convair_XC-99 "Convair XC-99") | 19471123 !23 November 1947 | Developed from B-36, single prototype was the largest piston-engined land-based transport aircraft ever built  
[Kawanishi H8K](/wiki/Kawanishi_H8K "Kawanishi H8K") | 19410100 !January 1941 | Largest World War II aircraft produced by Japan in any quantity (167 built)  
[Linke-Hofmann R.II](/wiki/Linke-Hofmann_R.II "Linke-Hofmann R.II") | 19190000 !1919 | Largest aircraft ever to fly with only one propeller, used largest airplane propeller ever used.  
[Lockheed C-5 Galaxy](/wiki/Lockheed_C-5_Galaxy "Lockheed C-5 Galaxy") | 19680630 !30 June 1968 | Largest USAF strategic airlifter and one of the largest military aircraft in the world  
[Martin JRM Mars](/wiki/Martin_JRM_Mars "Martin JRM Mars") | 19410000 !1941 | Largest flying boat to enter production (7 built)  
[Messerschmitt Me 323 "Gigant"](/wiki/Messerschmitt_Me_323 "Messerschmitt Me 323") | 19410000 !1941 | Biggest land-based cargo airplane during [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II")  
[Myasishchev VM-T](/wiki/Myasishchev_VM-T "Myasishchev VM-T") | 19810000 !1981 | Derivative of the [M-4](/wiki/Myasishchev_M-4 "Myasishchev M-4") as outsized cargo aircraft  
[Tupolev Tu-160](/wiki/Tupolev_Tu-160 "Tupolev Tu-160") | 19811218 !18 December 1981 | Heaviest combat aircraft, largest supersonic aircraft and largest swept-wing aircraft ever built.  
[Zeppelin-Staaken R.VI](/wiki/Zeppelin-Staaken_R.VI "Zeppelin-Staaken R.VI") | 19160000 !Circa 1916 | Largest aircraft to see regular squadron service (in 1917) in [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I")  
  
### Experimental and
prototypes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_large_aircraft&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Experimental and prototypes")]

Aircraft | First flight | Note  
---|---|---  
[Bristol Brabazon](/wiki/Bristol_Brabazon "Bristol Brabazon")[9] | 4 September 1949 | A giant luxurious airliner in which each passenger was given the space of the interior of a small car. There was no commercial interest and only the prototype flew.  
[Dassault Balzac](/wiki/Dassault_Balzac "Dassault Balzac") | 18 October 1962 | Experimental VTOL jet. MTOW 29,630 lb.  
[Douglas X-3 Stiletto](/wiki/Douglas_X-3_Stiletto "Douglas X-3 Stiletto") | 15 October 1952 | Supersonic research aircraft. Gross weight 22,100 lb.[10]  
[Ekranoplan KM](/wiki/Ekranoplan_KM "Ekranoplan KM") | 16 October 1966 | The ekranoplan had wingspan of 37.6 m, length - 92 m, maximum takeoff weight - 544 tons. Until An-225 it was the largest aircraft in the world. Unit KM was tested at the Caspian Sea for 15 years until 1980. In 1980, pilot error caused a crash without human casualties. The vehicle was too heavy to be recovered from its watery wrecksite.  
[Hughes H-4 Hercules](/wiki/Hughes_H-4_Hercules "Hughes H-4 Hercules") | 1947, 2 November | Largest aircraft in the world 1947 to 1952 when the even heavier [Boeing B-52 Stratofortress](/wiki/Boeing_B-52_Stratofortress "Boeing B-52 Stratofortress") first flew. World's largest flying boat, and largest wingspan of any aircraft. Only one was ever built and it performed only one short test flight. Commonly known as the "Spruce Goose".  
[Junkers Ju 390](/wiki/Junkers_Ju_390 "Junkers Ju 390") | 1943, 20 October | Largest aircraft in the world 1943 to 1944 when the even heavier [Blohm & Voss BV 238](/wiki/Blohm_%26_Voss_BV_238 "Blohm & Voss BV 238") first flew. Selected and further developed as the [Junkers](/wiki/Junkers "Junkers") firm's entry for the [Amerika Bomber](/wiki/Amerika_Bomber "Amerika Bomber") design contract.  
[North American XB-70 Valkyrie](/wiki/North_American_XB-70_Valkyrie "North American XB-70 Valkyrie") | 21 September 1964 | Prototype Mach 3 strategic bomber. Maximum takeoff weight 542,000 lb (246 tonnes).  
[Stratolaunch](/wiki/Scaled_Composites_Stratolaunch "Scaled Composites Stratolaunch") [11] | 2019 (Planned) | Stratolaunch is an aircraft currently under construction in Mojave, CA. With a wingspan of 385 ft (117 m), it will be the world’s largest aircraft by wingspan and the largest all-composite aircraft ever built. It is designed as an [aerial launch](/wiki/Air_launch "Air launch") platform, capable of lifting [orbital launch vehicles](/wiki/Launch_vehicle "Launch vehicle") weighing up to 550,000 lb (250 t) to an altitude of 45,000 ft (14,000 m). A nearly-complete aircraft was first shown on 1 June 2017.  
  
###
Projects[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_large_aircraft&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Projects")]

Aircraft | Design or Conception | Note  
---|---|---  
[Airbus A380-900](/wiki/Airbus_A380-900 "Airbus A380-900") | 2006 development | Announced in 2006 as a derivative of the Airbus A380-800. World's highest-capacity passenger aircraft in history. In May 2010, Airbus announced that A380-900 development was postponed, until production of the A380-800 has stabilised.[12]  
[Beriev Be-2500](/wiki/Beriev_Be-2500 "Beriev Be-2500") | 1980s proposal | Would be the largest aircraft ever, if built; development started in the 1980s  
[Boeing New Large Airplane](/wiki/Boeing_New_Large_Airplane "Boeing New Large Airplane") | 1990s proposal | Planned as a replacement for the 747, to be powered by the same engines used on the [777](/wiki/Boeing_777 "Boeing 777"). Project canceled in the 1990s due to the airline industry's lack of interest for very large aircraft.  
[Boeing Pelican](/wiki/Boeing_Pelican "Boeing Pelican") | 1990s proposal | Concept only for ground effect transport  
[Boeing 2707](/wiki/Boeing_2707 "Boeing 2707") SST | 1960s design. A mockup was built but no prototype. | Planned as an answer to the Anglo-French [Concorde](/wiki/Concorde "Concorde") supersonic transport (SST). At 306 feet (93 m) long it would have been one of the longest airframes ever flown. Problems with the weight of the swing-wing mechanism and air friction heating in Mach 3 flight provoked a drastic redesign, by which time airline interest in SSTs was dropping because of environmental concerns. There was also political opposition to funding private industry. The U.S. Congress cut government funding in 1971 and airlines began canceling orders.  
[McDonnell Douglas MD-12](/wiki/McDonnell_Douglas_MD-12 "McDonnell Douglas MD-12") | 1990 proposal | Proposed passenger aircraft, Designed to compete with the 747, project canceled in mid-1990s  
[Sukhoi KR-860](/wiki/Sukhoi_KR-860 "Sukhoi KR-860") | 1990s proposal | KR-860 (_Kryl 'ya Rossii_ or "Wings of Russia") early named as SKD-717 is super large transport aircraft with weights about 650 tonnes (Antonov An-225 weight is 600 tonnes), payload about 300 tonnes (An-225 payload is 250 tonnes) and 860 to 1000 passengers, a proposed Double decker wide-body superjumbo jet by Russian aerospace company Sukhoi.  
[Conroy Virtus](/wiki/Conroy_Virtus "Conroy Virtus") | 1974 | Proposed 140-metre wingspan aircraft capable of carrying Space Shuttle orbiter, or boosters, or Shuttle main tank  
"[Victory Bomber](/wiki/Victory_Bomber "Victory Bomber")" | 1940/41 | Proposed 50-ton 52-metre wingspan design by Barnes Wallis able to carry a ten-ton [earthquake bomb](/wiki/Earthquake_bomb "Earthquake bomb") (of his own design) and drop it from 14,000 m on strategic targets in Germany. Rejected by RAF due to lack of usefulness for other types of missions and unlikely to be completed before end of war.[13]  
[Skylon](/wiki/Skylon_\(spacecraft\) "Skylon \(spacecraft\)") | current | Proposed 345-tonne reusable spaceplane  
  
## Helicopters and rotary-wing
aircraft[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_large_aircraft&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Helicopters and rotary-wing aircraft")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Aeroflot_Mil_V-12_%28Mi-12%29_Groningen_Airport.jpg/220px-
Aeroflot_Mil_V-12_%28Mi-12%29_Groningen_Airport.jpg)](/wiki/File:Aeroflot_Mil_V-12_\(Mi-12\)_Groningen_Airport.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Aeroflot_Mil_V-12_\(Mi-12\)_Groningen_Airport.jpg "Enlarge")

[Aeroflot](/wiki/Aeroflot "Aeroflot") [Mil V-12](/wiki/Mil_V-12 "Mil V-12") at
[Groningen Airport](/wiki/Groningen_Airport "Groningen Airport") in May 1971.

Aircraft | First flight[Note 1] | Note  
---|---|---  
[Mil Mi-26](/wiki/Mil_Mi-26 "Mil Mi-26") | 1977, 14 December | Heaviest (56 tonnes), largest and most powerful helicopter in production ever.  
[Hughes XH-17](/wiki/Hughes_XH-17 "Hughes XH-17") | 1952 | Prototype heavy-lift helicopter with the largest rotor (129 ft) flown  
[V-22 Osprey](/wiki/V-22_Osprey "V-22 Osprey") | 1989, 19 March | One of the largest (27 tonnes) VTOL aircraft and the first operational tiltrotor  
[Mil Mi-10](/wiki/Mil_Mi-10 "Mil Mi-10") | 1960, 15 June | Heavy-lift "skycrane" developed from Mi-6, 114 ft rotor, 43 tonne MTOW  
[Mil V-12](/wiki/Mil_V-12 "Mil V-12") or Mi-12 | 1968, 10 July | Largest helicopter ever built; not put into production. 2 × 114 ft rotors, 105 tonnes MTOW.  
[Sikorsky Sea King](/wiki/Sikorsky_Sea_King "Sikorsky Sea King") |  | Many variants. Typ. MTOW 20,500 lb.  
[Sikorsky CH-53E Super Stallion](/wiki/Sikorsky_CH-53E_Super_Stallion "Sikorsky CH-53E Super Stallion") | 1981 | At 33 tonnes, largest helicopter in service with the US armed forces  
[Fairey Rotodyne](/wiki/Fairey_Rotodyne "Fairey Rotodyne") | 1957 | Largest compound gyroplane, 40 passenger capacity short haul airliner experiment  
  
  1. **Jump up ^** For designs that never flew the year of design or conception is used instead.

##
Airships[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_large_aircraft&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Airships")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Giant_Aircraft_Comparison.svg/300px-
Giant_Aircraft_Comparison.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Giant_Aircraft_Comparison.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Giant_Aircraft_Comparison.svg "Enlarge")

_Hindenburg airship compared with the largest fixed-wing aircraft._

Aircraft | First flight | Note  
---|---|---  
[HM Airship R100](/wiki/R100 "R100") | 1929, 16 December | 220 m, 146,000 m3  
[HM Airship R101](/wiki/R101 "R101") | 1929, 14 October | 236 m, 156,000 m3  
[R102](/wiki/R102 "R102") | Planned | Also known as 'Project H', planned 240,000 m3 airship. Cancelled along with possible 270,000 m3 R103  
[USS _Akron_](/wiki/USS_Akron_\(ZRS-4\) "USS Akron \(ZRS-4\)") | 1931, 8 August | 239 m, 180,000 m3 US Navy airship and largest helium-filled airship.  
[USS _Macon_](/wiki/USS_Macon_\(ZRS-5\) "USS Macon \(ZRS-5\)") | 1933, 23 June | Sister ship to _Akron_  
[LZ 129 _Hindenburg_](/wiki/LZ_129_Hindenburg "LZ 129 Hindenburg") | 1936, 4 April | 245 m, 200,000 m3 Largest volume aircraft ever flown, but only 215t.  
[LZ130 _Graf Zeppelin_](/wiki/LZ_130_Graf_Zeppelin "LZ 130 Graf Zeppelin") | 1938, 14 September | Sister ship to [LZ 129 _Hindenburg_](/wiki/LZ_129_Hindenburg "LZ 129 Hindenburg")  
[U.S. Navy ZPG-3W](/wiki/N-class_blimp "N-class blimp") | 1958, July | Largest-ever [United States Navy](/wiki/United_States_Navy "United States Navy") non-rigid airship, 1,011,000 cubic feet (23,648 cubic meters) envelope volume.  
[Hybrid Air Vehicles HAV 304 Airlander 10](/wiki/Hybrid_Air_Vehicles_HAV_304_Airlander_10 "Hybrid Air Vehicles HAV 304 Airlander 10") | 2016, 17 August | Largest-ever non-rigid airship/aircraft to fly, 38,000 m3 (1,300,000 cu ft) envelope volume. Longest heavier than air aircraft at 92m.
